text: the biggest myth about cavities is that
if it doesn't hurt you don't need to fix
it that is completely wrong by the time
a cavity hurts it's now usually not a
cabin not just the cavity it's usually a
problem that involves much more
extensive treatment than a simple
filling
when bacteria in your mouth consume
sugar the sugar produces acid and the
acid literally destroys the enamel that
covers the outside of your tooth
structure and once it destroys the
outside of your tooth structure it goes
into the tooth there are lots of reasons
that some people get more cavities than
others some people are not as great as
other people in brushing and flossing
brushing and flossing of course with the
best way to minimize the number of
cavities that you get some people are
not so great as others at watching their
dietary intake of added sugars the
stronger the outside surface of your
tooth structure the less likely you are
to have cavities the more sugar you
consume the more likely you are to have
cavities some people are just born with
tooth structure that is less highly
mineralized it's not as hard and strong
as the tooth structure in other people's
mouths for those people no matter how
much you brush or floss no matter how
much you constrain and restrict the
amount of added sugar that you consume
you always manage to find that you have
a couple cavities there are some things
that your dentist can do sometimes to
counterbalance that natural tendency for
your tooth structure to develop cavities
there are fluoride rinses their fluoride
mouth washes their fluoride treatments
lots of other things that your dentist
can prescribe to help you make your
tooth structure stronger to be less
resistant to cavities no matter what you
were born with so the best thing to do
is to see your dentist on a regular
basis so that your dentist can identify
cavities identify them when they're
small treat them when they're small
before they become much much bigger
problems than you'd ever bargained for
